title: River Otter and the Otter Estuary Walking Route

nearby.description: Otterton to Ladram Bay Circular Walk

images.title: Graham Horn / Otter estuary, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Otter estuary 1. These pine trees on the east side of the Otter estuary feature in many paintings and pictures of the Budleigh Salterton area. The shingle bank blocking the estuary is an extension of the Budleigh pebble beds, a distinct geological layer lying on top of the Triassic old red sandstone seen on the cliffs behind.

images.title: Mick Melvin / Otter Estuary, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Otter Estuary 2. The River Otter taken from the Pebble Bar at its mouth just before it reaches the sea

images.title: Trish Steel [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: In Otterton. A small tributary of the River Otter flows through the village, but it is at the moment dry.

images.title: Sarah Charlesworth / Building and Cross in front of Otterton Church, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Otterton Priory and Cross in front of Otterton Church. Above the porch of the priory, now in multiple occupation, exists the armorials of the Duke family sculpted in stone

images.title: Derek Harris / River Otter, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Otter. Section of the river approximately 100m south of aqueduct.

images.title: Andy Peacock / Cliffs at Budleigh Salterton., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cliffs at Budleigh Salterton. A good view of the South Devon rocks at the bottom of the Steamer Steps at Budleigh Salterton.

images.title: Mick Melvin / Budleigh Salterton, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Budleigh Salterton beach and sea view

images.title: Rob Purvis / The Salterton Arms, Chapel Street, Budleigh Salterton, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Salterton Arms, Chapel Street, Budleigh Salterton

description: Enjoy a lovely walk through the River Otter Valley on this waterside route near Budleigh Salterton. The walk starts from the village of Otterton and takes you along the River Otter to the Otter Estuary at Budleigh Salterton. The estuary is very pretty consisting of a variety of habitats including salt marsh, reed beds, low-lying meadows and pastureland. The Otter Estuary Nature reserve is a great place for bird watching. Look out for birds including cormorant, redshank, common sandpiper and curlew. You can enjoy a stroll along Budleigh Salterton beach before returning to Otterton along the river. At the coast you can pick up the South West Coast Path to extend your walk. Heading west will bring you to Exmouth, while Sidmouth and the beautiful Ladram Bay can be found in the other direction. At the secluded bay you will find a pair of striking sandstone sea stacks in a lovely spot with a small beach. Also nearby is the lovely Woodbury Common. Here you will find miles of walking trails through heathland and heather with an ancient hill fort to visit too.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: In Otterton head to the Kings Arms for some refreshments. The pub is in a delightful location next to the little mill stream that runs through the village. There's a good menu and drinks selection with a nice outdoor seating area for warmer days. It's also dog friendly. You can find the pub on Fore St, with a postcode of EX9 7HB for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head north from the estuary and you can link up with the Ottery St Mary Walk. This route visits the pretty riverside town which is notable for the 14th century St. Mary Church which includes a wonderful astronomical clock. The walk takes you along both sides of the river, visiting the nearby village of Tipton St John on the way. For more walking ideas in the area see the Devon Walks page.

display_address: The Green, Otterton, East Budleigh, East Devon, Devon, England, EX9 7HQ, United Kingdom
